div1.p: Pothier describes yellow fever outbreaks in Bucaramanga, Colombia.

div1.head: Letter extract from Oliver L. Pothier to Frederick F. Russell, July 19, 1923
div1.p: Extract of letter of July 19, 1923 from Dr. O. L. Pothier to Dr. F.F. Russell.

“When we met in Washington last Saturday week Dr. Carter
and you inquired into the vital statistics of Bucaramanga, of which
I was unable to give you definite information for the reasons given.
As for that of the epidemic of the fever of Bucaramanga here are
some additional facts which may be of some utility. In 1910 and
1911 there was an epidemic of fever, of the same character as the one
of 1923, in Bucaramanga and adjoining towns, which was more virulent
and more extensive, it was characterized by its large incidence and
its great mortality, during this invasion there were 341 fatal cases.
From the description of this epidemic, it corresponds in all its
aspects to the one that we found this year in Bucaramanga. This year
according to the report of Drs Daniel Peralta, Martin Carvajal,
Franciscao Pradiall Gonzelez, Andres Gomez, Julio Valdivieso, Roberto
Serpa, and Luis Ardila Gomez, they report 200 cases seen by them, of
which 80% were benign cases which recovered, 5% of the serious and
virulent cases who recovered, giving a total mortality of 15%. These
statictics only cover the cases seen by these Physicians. These
cases were only the cases seen by these Physicians, as I told you in
Washington when we arrived in Bucaramanga we were given a mortality
of 50% which we afterward interpreted to mean the mortality of severe
cases only, as I explained many of the mild cases had not been con-
cidered as many did not come under the observation of any physician.
On reading over the thesis of Dr. Carlos Esguerra, written in 1889
for his degree at the Medical School of Paris, he mentions epidemics
of yellow fever occurring at that period along the Magdelena river
and in Baranquilla. Since that time we have indications of peculiar
epidemics occurring in different ports along the Magdelena, Puerto
Berrio, The Fever of Tacamocho, a report of Dr. Emiliano Henao M.
which have all the characteristics of yellow fever, this report is
of 1917. It would seem that this fever must have existed for a long
period as an endemic condition for several years, and after disappearing
in the other foci remained endemic in the area of Bucaramanga and the
adjoining towns. I think I have covered all the information that
I have at my disposal that may elucidate the condition of endimicity at
Bucaramanga.”
